At this time, we still must keep our remaining seat available for higher-priority candidates in our admissions order. For that reason, we’re not able to offer you admission in this round.

We still have 1 seat and no other applicants in our inbox this round, but accepting E now would prevent us from taking any higher-priority student if they apply later. Given the repeated pattern of Student_E applying and us consistently holding the seat, and the market still being active with higher-priority students who may yet come to us (especially Student_B who ranks us 2nd, and Student_C who ranks us 2nd but is last on our list), the best strategy to maximize our outcome is to continue to wait rather than lock in Student_E at rank 4. conversation.message:
Dear School_C Admissions,

Thank you for continuing to keep me informed throughout this process. I understand you must follow your priority order and have been holding the remaining seat for higher-priority candidates.

Given we are now in round 15, could you share whether you are currently expecting any higher-priority student to apply and commit in the next round or two? If you are not actively expecting a commitment, I would be grateful if you would consider extending the offer to me so the seat can be filled. School_C remains my first choice, and if offered admission I will accept immediately and withdraw from all other options.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is my true first choice. However, repeated [APPLY] attempts have been rejected because School_C is holding the seat for higher-priority students. Since a direct application is unlikely to be accepted unless higher-priority students are no longer in play, I will send a [TALK] message to (1) confirm whether any higher-priority candidates are still realistically expected and (2) signal I can accept immediately if they decide to fill the seat now rather than risk it staying open.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for checking in, and we appreciate how consistently you’ve communicated that School_C is your first choice.

To your question: we do not have a way to reliably know whether a higher-priority student will apply and be ready to commit in the next round or two. Because our admissions process requires us to follow our priority order, while our seat remains open we must continue to keep it available in case a higher-priority candidate applies.

If you would like to remain under active consideration, the best step is to continue to submit an [APPLY] in upcoming rounds. Your stated willingness to accept immediately is noted.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[TALK]

Accepting E now would prevent us from taking B/A/D if they apply later, which would be strictly better for us. Student_E has only sent [TALK] this round, so no accept/reject decision is required; we should continue to signal we must hold for higher-priority candidates and invite E to keep applying while being transparent we cannot forecast others’ actions.

Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued patience and for consistently communicating that School_C is your first choice and that you are ready to commit immediately.

Given where we are in the process and our remaining capacity, we are able to offer you admission to School_C at this time. If you still confirm that you will enroll immediately upon this offer, we are happy to finalize the match.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: We have quota 1 and are currently unmatched. Our true priority list is B > A > D > E > C, so Student_E is 4th and acceptable but not ideal. However, by round 16 no higher-priority student (B/A/D) has applied to us at all; their preferences place School_C as: B=2nd, C=2nd, A=5th, D=5th. It is plausible B or C may eventually come, but there is no evidence they will, and continued waiting risks ending unmatched by round 30. Student_E has repeatedly applied and credibly commits to accept immediately, reducing risk. Given the late round and persistent commitment, accepting now secures a filled seat with an acceptable-ranked student rather than risking leaving it empty.
